Module 1 Homework: AI-Assisted Coding and Exploratory Data Analysis

Instructions

This homework is meant to be completed with AI assistance (such as an in-browser LLM like ChatGPT, and/or using a CLI like Claude Code) to practice scaling your data exploration work.

For all questions, submit:

  1. Your code (in a .py file or Jupyter notebook)
  2. All visualizations generated
  3. Written answers to interpretation questions (can be in markdown or comments)
  4. The prompts you used with the AI assistant(s)

Dataset

You’ll be working with a dataset called housing_data.csv which contains information about houses sold in various cities. The dataset includes:

  • price: Sale price in dollars
  • square_feet: Size of the house
  • bedrooms: Number of bedrooms
  • bathrooms: Number of bathrooms
  • year_built: Year the house was built
  • city: City where the house is located
  • lot_size: Size of the lot in square feet
  • garage_spaces: Number of garage spaces
  • has_pool: Whether the house has a pool (True/False)

Questions

Question 0:

  • Which LLM assistant(s) did you use? Be specific. For example, “I used ChatGPT in the browser”, or “I used Claude Code in the terminal”.

Question 1 (5 points)

Use AI to create a comprehensive data profile that includes:

  • Summary statistics for ALL numerical columns (not just price)
  • Value counts for ALL categorical columns
  • A report on missing values (which columns, how many, what percentage)
  • Identification of potential outliers in numerical columns (using percentile method: values below 1st or above 99th percentile)

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code generated
  • The output/report

Question 2 (5 points)

Prompt the AI to create a function that generates a complete set of univariate visualizations for the dataset. This should include:

  • Histograms for all numerical columns
  • Bar plots for all categorical columns
  • All plots should be saved to a folder called univariate_plots/
  • Each plot should have proper labels and titles

Run the function and submit all generated plots along with your code.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • All generated visualizations

Question 3 (5 points)

Use AI to create a pair plot (using sns.pairplot()) showing relationships between key numerical variables: price, square_feet, bedrooms, and year_built. Color the points by city.

Based on the pair plot, answer:

  • Which pair of variables shows the strongest visual relationship?
  • Are there any variables that don’t seem to relate to price?
  • Do you notice any city-specific patterns?

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The pair plot visualization
  • Your written interpretation (3-4 sentences)

Question 4 (6 points)

Prompt the AI to create a function that compares price distributions across different subgroups. Specifically:

  • Compare price by city
  • Compare price by number of bedrooms
  • Compare price by whether the house has a pool
  • Generate both statistical summaries AND visualizations (box plots or violin plots)

Run this function and write 2-3 paragraphs interpreting the results. What insights did you gain about what drives housing prices?

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • All visualizations
  • Your written interpretation

Question 5 (6 points)

Ask the AI to help you identify potential outliers in the price column. Your approach should:

  • Define outliers as values below the 1st percentile or above the 99th percentile
  • Create visualizations showing the distribution with outliers highlighted
  • Display summary statistics for the full dataset and for data excluding outliers
  • Investigate the outliers: are they data errors or legitimate expensive/cheap houses?

How many potential outliers did you identify? Should they be removed, or do they represent legitimate data points? Justify your answer.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • Visualizations showing outliers
  • Written analysis (4-5 sentences)

Question 6 (6 points)

Use AI to create a comprehensive test suite for the housing dataset. Your test suite should include at least 5 unit tests that check:

  • Data types are correct
  • No negative values in columns where they don’t make sense (price, square_feet, etc.)
  • Dates are within reasonable ranges (year_built should be between 1800 and 2024)
  • Categorical values are from expected sets (cities should only be from a known list)
  • No duplicate rows

Run all tests and report which (if any) failed.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The complete test suite code
  • Test results

Question 7 (5 points)

Prompt the AI to create multiple scatter plots exploring the relationship between price and other numerical variables. You should generate:

  • Price vs. square_feet (colored by city)
  • Price vs. year_built (colored by has_pool)
  • Price vs. lot_size (with a trend line)
  • Price_per_sqft vs. bedrooms (colored by city)

For each plot, write 1-2 sentences describing what you observe.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • All scatter plots
  • Your written observations

Question 8 (6 points)

Use AI to create a function that systematically explores how price relates to ALL categorical variables in the dataset. For each categorical variable, the function should:

  • Create a bar plot showing average price by category
  • Generate a box plot showing the distribution of prices across categories
  • Calculate and display summary statistics (mean, median, count) for each category
  • Save all plots to a folder called categorical_analysis/

Run this function and write a paragraph identifying which categorical variables seem most important in determining house prices.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The function code
  • All generated visualizations
  • Your written analysis

Question 9 (6 points)

Use AI to create a function that performs a complete exploratory data analysis for ANY numerical column in the dataset. The function should:

  • Take a DataFrame and column name as inputs
  • Generate: histogram, box plot, and summary statistics
  • Identify potential outliers using percentiles (values below 1st or above 99th percentile)
  • Create a markdown-formatted report with findings
  • Save all plots to a specified folder

Run this function on three different columns: price, square_feet, and lot_size.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The function code
  • All generated visualizations
  • The markdown reports for each column

Question 10 (7 points)

For this final question, ask the AI to help you create a comprehensive EDA report. This should be a multi-page visualization that includes:

  • Overall dataset summary (rows, columns, missing values)
  • Distribution plots for key numerical variables
  • Correlation analysis
  • Price analysis by different categorical variables
  • Any interesting patterns or anomalies you discovered

Write a 1-page executive summary (300-400 words) that you would present to a stakeholder who doesn’t know anything about data science. Explain:

  • What the dataset contains
  • Key findings from your analysis
  • What factors seem most important in determining house prices
  • Any data quality issues or limitations
  • Recommendations for next steps

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • All visualizations in your EDA report
  • Your executive summary
  • Reflection: How did using AI change your approach to this comprehensive analysis compared to doing it by hand?

Submission Guidelines

Submit a ZIP file containing one folder for each problem. Within each folder you should have one file for each of the following:

  1. Code files: All .py files or Jupyter notebooks
  2. Visualizations folder: All plots and charts generated
  3. Written responses: A single document (PDF or Markdown) with all your written answers, interpretations, and AI prompts used
  4. Data: Include your cleaned/modified datasets if you created any

Tips for Success

  • Write specific, detailed prompts
  • If the AI’s first attempt isn’t quite right, refine your prompt
  • Always review and test the AI-generated code
  • Don’t just accept AI output—understand what it’s doing
  • Include context in your prompts (e.g., “I’m working with a housing dataset with columns…”)

General:

  • Start early—EDA often reveals unexpected issues that take time to address
  • Your interpretations are just as important as your code
  • If you find something interesting in the data, explore it further!
  • Use your brain. That’s what it’s there for.
